Screen.name: menu
Screen.Text: This game is a cyberpunk text adventure.
It was made by Nathaniel Nelson for the Cyberpunk Game Jam using SDL.
You can find more similar & awesome games at itch.io/jam/cyberpunk-jam
Play by making choices with the number keys.

Screen.name: intro1
Screen.Text: CHAPTER ONE
On the day you turn 16, your parents take you to get your first aug.
Driving to the clinic, you distract yourself from the nervous anticipation by gazing out the window.
A sad-looking homeless man catches your eye.

Screen.name: intro2
Screen.Text: You avert your gaze and put the man out of mind.
The man briefly meets your gaze. He appears to be a normal, unaugmented human being. You see profound sorrow in his eyes. He is soon far behind you.
Your thoughts return to your first aug. You haven't made up your mind yet.

Action.text: "Can we go over my options again?"

Screen.name: intro3
Screen.Text: Your parents outline the choices. Because you are still young, your first augs will be completely temporary and must be replaced as you grow.

Your mother encourages you to try mental augmentation - you can optimize your internal processing by placing a microchip in your cranium to interface with your brain. This seems dangerous, but she assures you the tech has been well tested and is quite safe.
Your father suggests a simple strength enhancement. They will use nanobots to boost your muscles' strength and efficiency.

As an afterthought, they mention the agility aug. You can increase your reaction time, coordination and speed. Your parents aren't sure how it works (though you imagine it's similar to the strength enhancement).

Screen.name: intro4
Screen.Text: You finally arrive at the clinic.
You step out of the car and onto the pavement. You've never been to this clinic before - it is surprisingly small. Augs are still too expensive for the general population. Maybe always will be.

You step out of the car and onto the pavement. You've never been to this clinic before - it is surprisingly small. Augs are still too expensive for the general population. Maybe always will be. Somehow you doubt it.
The automatic door slides open and a synthetic voice greets you: "Welcome to the Delta One Augmentation Clinic!"
Inside, an animated face watches you from a screen in the wall. It asks for your name, and tells you to sit for a few moments until the doctor is ready for you.

Screen.name: intro5
Screen.Text: You've sat for long enough today. You stay standing.
You take a seat next to your parents.
In less than 15 minutes, another door opens and the doctor enters. You say hello.
In less than 15 minutes, another door opens and the doctor enters. You stand and say hello.
Your parents stay back. He leads you to the operating room and asks what kind of augmentation you'll be receiving today.

Screen.name: intro6
Screen.Text: The doctor notes your choice and has you lay on the operating table. You inhale a pleasant-smelling gas and drift off.

Screen.name: intro7
Screen.Text: You drift back into consciousness after the operation is complete.
You reach up and feel your head - it's wrapped in bandages and your hair has been shaved.
You don't actually notice anything different about your body.
You don't actually notice anything different about your body.
You rejoin your parents and drive home.
CHAPTER TWO
You wake up the next morning to soft music as the sun's first rays shine in through the window. Your home computer system pumps the sound in every morning at 6:00 AM.
You have a splitting headache. You feel your bandages - everything seems normal.
You feel great.
You feel great.
The pain is almost unbearable. You take some sleeping pills, close the blinds, and return to bed.
When you awake, the day has already gone by. It's dark outside. The pain has been reduced to a dull throb.
Feeling awake and alert, you leave bed and sit at the computer terminal.
You finish two school days worth of work in under an hour.
You sit at the terminal.

Screen.name: 2-2-news
Screen.Text: You read for hours about the state of the world. Augmentation technology is rolling out all over the world, slowly. The wealthiest cities in the world embrace it rapidly. Many countries have yet to build a single augmentation clinic.

People are unsure how to respond to such revolutionary changes. Some reject augmentation, and some call for it to be outlawed. There is mistrust of the scientists and companies behind augmentations. "What if they abuse their power?" many ask.
Bugs and cameras keep silent watch over the people. No one knows to whom these eyes belong - most ignore them, but many resent their presence.
Eventually the sun starts to rise. Your terminal interrupts you at 6:00 AM with a reminder to get ready for school.
